title: MSc, Ecology and Evolutionary Biology
description_1: Thesis: “Variable light conditions affect warning signal efficacy in an aposematic polymorphic moth”; Grade: 4/5.
description_2: My degree was graded as “Excellent”, the highest grade awarded to degrees at JYU
description_3: Supervised by Phd Ossi Nokelainen and Prof. Johanna Mappes

title: BSc, Biological Sciences
description_1: Monograph: “What drives changes in composition of ant assemblages along a vertical gradient?”
description_3: Supervised by Profs. Fernando Augusto Schmidt and José Henrique Schoreder

title: Visiting student
description_1: Attended Master's level courses and did an internship at the research group “Social Evolution in Ants”

title: Master’s thesis development
description_1: I did my thesis work in Professor Johanna Mappe's group. I investigated the effects of different light conditions affected the predation pressure suffered by Actia plantaginis, an aposematic species that is also color polymorphic. I also attended the group's weekly meetings during which we discussed papers, and presented research projects.

title: Research apprentice
description_1: I was part of different ant community ecology and biodiversity research projects, and conducted the project that resulted in my bachelor’s monograph. I had experience with sampling and identifying ants, data analysis and scientific writing, among other activities related to the research group.

title: Research apprentice
description_1: I worked as research apprentice in the group “Social Evolution in Ants” during my exchange year at University of Helsinki. I was part of projects related to ecology, evolution, behaviour, and population biology of Formica and Myrmica ants. I had experience with sampling and sorting ant colonies, setting-up and maintaining experimental colonies in the lab and recording results from lab experiments. I also helped with mark/recapture sampling and survival assays using ants.

title: [News on the enigmatic ant genus Anillidris (Formicidae: Dolichoderinae: Leptomyrmecini)](https://myrmecologicalnews.org/cms/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&id=576&Itemid=363)
description_1: SCHMIDT, F. A. ; FEITOSA, R. M. ; **DE MORAES REZENDE, F.** ; SILVA DE JESUS, R.

title: What drives changes in composition of ant assemblages along a vertical gradient?
institution: XXII Simpósio de Mirmecologia: An International Ant Meeting, Ilhéus, Brasil
description_1: **_REZENDE, F. M._** ; JESUS, R. S. ; RIBAS, C. R., SCHOEREDER, J. H.
description_2: This talk won the prize for best oral presentation in its category

title: Os últimos serão os primeiros? Distribuição de abortos no fruto de _Leucaena leucocephala (Lam.)_ de Witt
description_1: I presented the talk “Os últimos serão os primeiros? Distribuição de abortos no fruto de _Leucaena leucocephala (Lam.)_ de Witt” as part of the activities of  EcoEncontros---a weekly meeting organized by graduate students from theUniversidade de São Paulo's (USP) Graduate Program in Ecology. This talk was about the project developed by my group during the “2^a^ EcoEscola: Escola de Ecologia da USP”. My group investigated a possible selective abortion pattern in _L. leucocephala’s_ pods and its relationship to post copulatory cryptic female choice. Our hypothesis was that we would find significantly more abortions on the basal end of the pods. We did not find any clear abortion pattern in the pods.

title: Evolution tutor
description_1: Worked as tutor in the course “BIO 340 — Evolução Orgânica” (Organic Evolution) for one semester. My duties were to assist the students within and without class hours, to evaluate the students’ reports and extra tasks, to help the students prepare their seminars and to elaborate questions during the presentation of said seminars.
description_2: This was a voluntary position (i.e., I was not paid)

title: Ecology tutor
description_1: Worked as a tutor in the course “BIO 131 — Ecologia Básica” (Basic Ecology) for three semesters. My duties consisted of assisting the students during the practical lessons, evaluating the reports made by the students and conducting a weekly meeting to help the students with any content related doubts. I also helped the professors during the I, II & III Mostra de trabalhos de ecologia básica. These were mini symposia in which the students presented projects conducted during the course using the scientific method. My duties were to supervise and evaluate some of these projects.
description_2: I received a scholarship as a compensation for my work in this position

title: Processo de apodrecimento de troncos caídos no solo e a diversidade de formigas
institution: XXIV Congresso Brasileiro de Entomologia, Curitiba, Brasil
description_1: CHAUL, J. C. M. ; **_REZENDE, F. M._**
description_2: We investigated how the richness of the ant communities present in fallen logs was influenced by how rot these logs were. Our hypothesis was that we would find more ant species when the logs were at a moderate state of decay. We did not find a significant relationship between the studied variables

title: R
description_1: I can analyze data using LMs, GLMs, GLMMs and conduct survival analyses. I can produce bar plots, line graphs, scatter plots, and histograms using R’s base graphics device and ggplot2. Finally, I know enough programming in R to clean and organize/sort data. I also know enough R to look for help online and implement it on my own provided that I have some time to work on it.

title: Latex
description_1: I can produce my own simple documents, including presentations and I know enough to implement different templates when necessary

title: Python
description_1: I can do basic data manipulation and plotting

title: Bash
description_1: I can write scripts to manipulate data and automate tasks

title: [Computational and data literacy](https://www.nhm.ac.uk/our-science/courses-and-students/advancing-computational-and-data-literacy-for-life-scientists.html)
description_1: Duration: June 4 – June 8
description_2: Course on reproducible data analysis and management, including data wrangling, Git and Github, R Markdown, and the basics of data analysis and visualisation using R.

title: International summer school on lake ecology and management,
description_1: Duration: August 24 – September 2
description_2: This summer school focused on lake ecology and management in the 21^st^ century, new technologies for lake research and sustainable management developed in cooperation with stakeholders

title: 2^a^ EcoEscola: Escola de Ecologia da USP
description_1: Duration: July 27 – August 14 (92 hours altogether)
description_2: A three-week long course on ecology organized by the students of USP’s Graduate Program in Ecology. It consisted of two modules. The first module happened from July 27 to July 31 and it consisted of three mini-symposia (one about ecology applied to conservation, one about ecology & evolution and one about ecological interactions). The second module happened from August 3 to August 14. It consisted of lectures about the scientific method, data analysis and presentation, among other topics. We also developed, executed and presented a project on ecology. For further information on this course please write ecoescola@ib.usp.br

title: III Formigas do Brasil
description_1: Duration: September 7 – September 14  (56 hours altogether)
description_2: A course on Brazilian mirmecology. It included lectures about ecology, taxonomy, phylogeny, ant identification and sampling. Additionally, we had a field trip to the Cerrado (a Brazilian biome similar to the African Savannas) to apply some of the sampling techniques that we learned during the course.

title: Taxonomy, Identification and Ecology of European Ants
description_1: Duration: August 24 – August 29 (4 ECTS)
description_2: Similar to “III Formigas do Brasil” but focusing on European ants. Besides the previously described topics, this course dealt chemical ecology and molecular methods. We also went on a field trip to learn/apply sampling techniques.

title: XI Curso de Verão em Entomologia
institution: University of São Paulo --- Ribeirão Preto _campus_
description_1: January 28 – February 8 (90 hours altogether)
description_2: An entomology summer school. We learned the basics about ecology, evolution, phylogeny, biogeography and behavior of several different Insecta groups. We also learned several sampling techniques used to samples insects and applied them on a short field trip.
